title: Advanced Conditionals & Hypothetical Structures
description: Master mixed conditionals and sophisticated hypothetical expressions.

rules.title: Mixed Conditionals: Past Condition, Present Result
rules.explanation: Use this structure when a past situation has an ongoing present consequence. The if-clause uses past perfect, while the main clause uses would + base verb.
rules.structure: If + past perfect, would + base verb

examples.sentence: If I had studied medicine, I would be a doctor now.
examples.translation: 내가 의학을 공부했더라면, 지금 의사일 텐데.

examples.sentence: If she hadn't moved abroad, she would still live in Seoul.
examples.translation: 그녀가 해외로 이주하지 않았더라면, 아직도 서울에 살고 있을 텐데.

examples.sentence: If they had invested wisely, they wouldn't be struggling financially.
examples.translation: 그들이 현명하게 투자했더라면, 재정적으로 어려움을 겪지 않을 텐데.

rules.title: Mixed Conditionals: Present Condition, Past Result
rules.explanation: Use this structure when a general present truth would have affected a past situation. The if-clause uses simple past, while the main clause uses would have + past participle.
rules.structure: If + simple past, would have + past participle

examples.sentence: If I weren't so busy, I would have attended the conference.
examples.translation: 내가 그렇게 바쁘지 않았다면, 컨퍼런스에 참석했을 텐데.

examples.sentence: If he spoke Japanese, he would have gotten the job in Tokyo.
examples.translation: 그가 일본어를 했다면, 도쿄에서 그 일자리를 얻었을 텐데.

examples.sentence: If the company were more flexible, they wouldn't have lost so many employees.
examples.translation: 회사가 더 유연했다면, 그렇게 많은 직원을 잃지 않았을 텐데.

rules.title: Inversion in Conditionals
rules.explanation: In formal writing and speech, conditional sentences can begin with an inverted auxiliary verb instead of 'if'. This adds emphasis and formality.

examples.sentence: Had I known about the problem, I would have addressed it immediately.
examples.translation: 그 문제에 대해 알았더라면, 즉시 처리했을 텐데.

examples.sentence: Were the situation to change, we would reconsider our position.
examples.translation: 상황이 바뀐다면, 우리의 입장을 재고할 것이다.

examples.sentence: Should you require any assistance, please do not hesitate to contact us.
examples.translation: 도움이 필요하시면, 주저 없이 연락해 주십시오.

rules.title: Subjunctive with 'Wish' and 'If Only'
rules.explanation: Use subjunctive structures with 'wish' and 'if only' to express regret about the past, dissatisfaction with the present, or desires for the future.
rules.structure: Wish/If only + past simple (present) / past perfect (past) / would + base verb (future)

examples.sentence: I wish I had more time to dedicate to this project. (present)
examples.translation: 이 프로젝트에 더 많은 시간을 할애할 수 있으면 좋겠다.

examples.sentence: If only we had anticipated this outcome. (past)
examples.translation: 우리가 이 결과를 예상했더라면 좋았을 텐데.

examples.sentence: I wish the committee would reconsider their decision. (future/request)
examples.translation: 위원회가 그들의 결정을 재고해 주면 좋겠다.

exercises.question: If I _____ more assertive, I would have asked for a promotion last year.
exercises.explanation: This is a mixed conditional: present condition (general truth about personality) affecting a past result. Use 'were' for the present unreal condition.

exercises.question: _____ the experiment been conducted properly, the results would be more reliable.
exercises.explanation: This uses inversion for a past conditional. 'Had the experiment been conducted' = 'If the experiment had been conducted'.

exercises.question: If she hadn't resigned, she _____ CEO by now.
exercises.explanation: This is a mixed conditional: past condition (she resigned) with present result (she is not CEO now). Use 'would be' for the present hypothetical result.

exercises.question: _____ you need any further information, please let me know.
exercises.explanation: 'Should you need' is a formal, inverted conditional meaning 'If you should need'. It's commonly used in business correspondence.

exercises.question: I wish the government _____ more transparent about their policies.
exercises.explanation: After 'wish', use past subjunctive 'were' to express a desire about the present situation. 'Were' is used for all persons in formal subjunctive.
